source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk1

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Bourgeois and Chirigos [6] reported that alpha-annealed Zircaloy-2 formed a non-adherent white oxide after 1 day at 510 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: beta-quenched specimens were more resistant, but 0.080-in. thick specimens failed completely between 15 and 21 days

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: Weinstein and Holtz [7] found that Zircaloy-2 disintegrated in steam at 480 C within 97 h

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: The standard steam pressure was 1700 psig at all temperatures; however, conditions in one test were 4000 psig at 450 C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk1
evidence_span: The autoclaves were operated at a low refreshment rate (0.3 gal/h); the autoclave volume is 1.6 gal

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk2

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk2

evidence_span: Certain as-etched specimen surfaces were contaminated with localized smears of aluminun and iron

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk2
evidence_span: Selected specimens were vacuum annealed in the $\pmb { \alpha }$ region $( 7 6 0 \mathrm { C } , 8 \mathrm { ~ h } )$ and the $\beta$ region (1010 C, 15 min, fast-cooled) followed by a standard chemical etch $( \mathrm { H F + H N O _ { 3 } + H _ { 2 } O }$ solution) prior to autoclave exposure at $5 0 0 \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk2
evidence_span: Weight gains as a function of temperature, time, and alloy appear in Fig. I for a series of autoclave experiments in stean at 1700 psig

evidence_span: The $5 0 0 \mathrm { C }$ test produced high weight gains and disintegration of some specimens during the $^ { 2 4 \cdot \mathrm { h } }$ exposure

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk3

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: failure was essentially complete after 7 days

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: Alpha-annealed specimens resisted the nodular attack and rapid failure, but began to spall after approximately 7 days.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: specinens with a beta anneal resisted the nodular attack and did not begin to spall appreciably until about 36 days in the case of lot 1021 Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: 70 days in the case of lot 42-0 Zircaloy-2.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: Prefilming at $3 6 0 ~ \mathrm { C }$ did not suppress the nodular attack.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: Abrading with emery paper induced a rapid attack on alpha-annealed specimens but not on beta-annealed, fast-cooled specimens.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_020_chunk3
evidence_span: Crystal bar zirconium with alpha and beta heat treatments failed within $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ .
